speaker: ME
text: Um I guess Real Reaction did some market research .

speaker: ME
text: They had a hundred subjects and their usability lab

speaker: ME
text: and they watched them watch T_V_

speaker: ME
text: and recorded the frequency that they used particular buttons and the relevance that those buttons had .

speaker: ME
text: What they found was they analysed people's desires and needs .

speaker: ME
text: Focusing on their desires , um people specifically said that they thought remotes were ugly <vocalsound> ,

speaker: ME
text: seventy five per cent of the a hundred subjects noted that

speaker: ME
text: more importantly though , eighty per cent said that they would be willing to pay more for a fancier looking remote .

speaker: ME
text: I don't know anything beyond what fancy means ,

speaker: ME
text: but that's particularly of use to us , I think .

speaker: ME
text: Um also they did some questions on voice recognition

speaker: ME
text: and found that the desire for voice recognition was inversely related to age ,

speaker: ME
text: so younger people were more inclined to want something with voice recognition ,

speaker: ME
text: whereas the older people in the like sixty and above segment or so did not really think that they would pay more money for voice recognitions .

speaker: ME
text: Um people also had certain frustrations ,

speaker: ME
text: that I think that we could try to take into consideration with our design .

speaker: ME
text: That being people k um frustrated with losing their remotes .

speaker: ME
text: I think , over fifty percent of the people mentioned that that was their biggest frustration .

speaker: ME
text: People are also frustrated with the difficulty it is to learn how to use a remote

speaker: ME
text: and I think that ties back to what you were saying before

speaker: ME
text: just that there's too many buttons ,

speaker: ME
text: it just needs to be easy to use .

speaker: ME
text: It also mentioned something called R_S_I_

speaker: ME
text: and I was hoping someone might be able to inform me as to what R_S_I_ is ,

speaker: ME
text: So I guess sort of the carpal tunnel type thing , people do not like that ,

speaker: ME
text: um the repetitive use , I guess , caused a strain .

speaker: ME
text: Um looking at the needs people specified , the problem right now is that people's remotes are not matching their operating behaviour .

speaker: ME
text: People are only using ten per cent of the buttons that they have offered to them on their remote .

speaker: ME
text: And what people do most often is changing the channel and changing the volume .

speaker: ME
text: People also zap like to change the channel , about um sixty five per cent during an hour of use .

speaker: ME
text: So we really just need to focus in on those volumes and channel changers rather than things like the audio settings , the screen settings and the channel settings ,

speaker: ME
text: because they're used much more infrequently

speaker: ME
text: and probably just complicate what's going on .

speaker: ME
text: So I think that some things that we might wanna think about ,

speaker: ME
text: the idea of an L_C_D_ screen was brought up

speaker: ME
text: although they didn't have any details on what people's preferences on that were ,

speaker: ME
text: so I dunno know if that's coming to me later , or something like that .

speaker: ME

speaker: ME
text: also just the phenomenon that less is more when it comes to the buttons on the remote

speaker: ME
text: or what we wanna make easiest to use ,

speaker: ME
text: make sure that , you know , something like an audio setting isn't given as much importance and visibility on the remote as something like channel changing that's used a lot more often .

speaker: UI
text: We need to start by considering what a remote control actually is .

speaker: UI
text: It's a device that allows us to produce certain effects on our television ,

speaker: UI
text: so i it's basically a communication device .

speaker: UI
text: We we tell the remote control what we want to do ,

speaker: UI
text: it sends a message to the television

speaker: UI
text: Um how do we actually go about designing a new television remote control ?

speaker: UI
text: First thing to do is to come up with the design specifications .

speaker: UI
text: We need to know what our final product is gonna be like ,

speaker: UI
text: so we need a a clear idea of exactly what this product does ,

speaker: UI
text: and what the end-user is gonna want from this product .

speaker: UI
text: a way I'd suggest that we could go about this is by designing uh several different prototypes of user interfaces for this product ,

speaker: UI
text: um and then uh trying to get some feedback uh about

speaker: UI
text: h how well these particular prototypes work ,

speaker: UI
text: uh sorta find out what people think of 'em .

speaker: UI
text: Um using a remote control is is quite a subjective experience . Um ,

speaker: UI
text: and different different people sort of prefer different things .

speaker: UI
text: Um we should remember that remote controls are a a fairly standard piece of equipment .

speaker: UI
text: When a users using a remote control , he or she expects the buttons to be in certain places .

speaker: UI
text: So in some sense we're gonna we're gonna have to aim for a device which is fairly conventional in design

speaker: UI
text: uh so that we're not completely shocking people .

speaker: UI
text: But I think within that there is also room for us to introduce novel ideas

speaker: UI
text: uh and to make something that's that's perhaps a little bit different , something that stands out .

speaker: UI
text: Um also in in designing the user interface we need to consider practicalities .

speaker: UI
text: Uh the first of these is is technological

speaker: UI
text: uh what can we do with the current state of technology as it is .

speaker: UI
text: uh we need to find a balance between features and price .

speaker: UI
text: things like voice recognition would would add to the price

speaker: UI
text: uh but it would also im improve the design of the product .

speaker: UI
text: I had a look on the <disfmarker> on the web uh to see if I could find a few examples of existing television remote controls .

speaker: UI
text: In analysing these we can consider what what things <disfmarker> what's good about them ,

speaker: UI
text: uh what things do they get right ,

speaker: UI
text: um how we can improve on the designs that that that I found

speaker: UI
text: and what can we do to make our product stand out from from the large majority of remote controls .

speaker: UI
text: Here's two examples uh probably at the extreme ends of the spectrum .

speaker: UI
text: Um on the left here we've got uh an engineering-based design for a remote control ,

speaker: UI
text: so it's one that's got lots of buttons ,

speaker: UI
text: everything you might possibly want to do is there ,

speaker: UI
text: you know , it's got forward , backwards , up , down , channel numbers , volume , uh freeze frame .

speaker: UI
text: and it might take a while to get to learn to use it ,

speaker: UI
text: but once you've learned it you can <disfmarker> you can do whatever you want with your T_V_ .

speaker: UI
text: The one on the right is a lot more basic .

speaker: UI
text: It would be a lot quicker to learn to use it ,

speaker: UI
text: but again th it's it's swings and roundabouts .

speaker: UI
text: you can't use it say to to freeze the television picture .

speaker: UI
text: Uh there's a lot of features that are missing from that remote control .

speaker: UI
text: So we've got to to find our <disfmarker> find a way of striking a balance between the two .
